awd_titl_txt: Belmont Forum Collaborative Research: Marine Research and Innovation for a Sustainable management of Coasts and Oceans (MARISCO)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support to U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 55-country initiative on global change research through the Belmont Forum.  The Belmont Forum is a consortium of research funding organizations focused on support for transdisciplinary approaches to global environmental change challenges and opportunities.  It aims to accelerate delivery of the international research most urgently needed to remove critical barriers to sustainability by aligning and mobilizing international resources. Each partner country provides funding for their researchers within a consortium to alleviate the need for funds to cross international borders. This approach facilitates effective leveraging of national resources to support excellent research on topics of global relevance best tackled through a multinational approach, recognizing that global challenges need global solutions.

Working together in this Collaborative Research Action, the partner agencies have provided support to foster global transdisciplinary research teams to address critical issues in ocean sustainability including, conservation and sustainable use of the oceans, seas and marine resources for sustainable development.  This complex challenge required that the projects utilized integrated, transdisciplinary and cross-sectoral approaches and bring together natural and social sciences as well as policymakers, resource managers, industries, citizens and other societal partners.  This award provides support for the U.S. researchers to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries to increase our knowledge of the complex linkages and pathways needed to accelerate sustainable use of oceans and minimize the effects from global change.  

This project focuses on developing, merging and synthesizing transdisciplinary, global knowledge for understanding the consequences of human actions for coastal and ocean sustainability and produce strategies and tools for effective management. Data analysis and model development of coastal marine ecosystems will be conducted utilizing both natural and social science expertise with the goal of defining the feedback loops within different aspects of biodiversity change and Nature’s Contributions to People. This project will develop, merge and synthesize transdisciplinary, global knowledge for understanding the consequences of human actions for coastal and ocean sustainability and produce strategies and tools for effective management.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
By understanding the impacts of human activities on marine ecosystems, we can better inform policy and management strategies that will help sustain the marine services that are directly important to human well-being, such as fisheries, tourism and recreation, and coastal livelihoods.  Despite advances in these fields, our understanding of how human activities will impact marine environments is hindered by gaps in our knowledge about how marine species will respond to pressures from each human activity, and how cumulative pressures, and ultimately, impacts will change in the future. In this project we made significant advances to address each of these limitations.

We first developed a framework to estimate the vulnerability of species to a suite of marine pressures given their life-history traits, such as their reproduction, growth, and lifespan. This framework allowed us to assess the vulnerability of tens of thousands of species - even those with limited data - to a suite of marine pressures. To determine which areas and taxa are currently most impacted by human activities, we then overlaid the species range and vulnerability data with maps of human pressure intensity.

These efforts were complimented by projects with partners in South Africa, which contributed to conservation initiatives aimed at protecting vulnerable marine species, such as the critically endangered humpback dolphins along the coast of South Africa, and work by partners in Germany who developed local trait-based vulnerability models using long-term monitoring data from coastal areas in Germany and South Africa.

To be successful, management plans must incorporate information about the future, however, the pressures facing marine environments are less studied and understood than terrestrial pressures. To address this gap, we reviewed the state of our current scientific knowledge on how human-induced pressures are likely to change in the future. This review allowed us to better understand the future trajectory of marine pressures, as well as identify critical gaps in research and policy that need urgent attention. By synthesizing existing knowledge, we highlighted the most pressing areas where future research and policy initiatives should focus to effectively protect marine life.

Building upon this foundation, we explored how marine systems will be impacted by human activities in the near future (i.e., 2050). To begin, we produced maps describing the current and future projected marine pressures for different climate scenarios for as many pressures as possible. We then overlayed these data with habitat distributions and vulnerabilities to determine which global regions are facing the largest future threats based on the cumulative impacts of multiple human stressors on marine ecosystems.

Overall, this project enhanced our scientific understanding and provided essential information and data about the variability and intensity of human impacts to marine biodiversity, helping facilitate informed and proactive management of marine ecosystems and thus contributing directly to global conservation goals.
